an8.73:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā nātike viharati giñjakāvasathe.
an8.73:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying at Ñātika in the brick house.

an8.73:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

an8.73:1.6.pli: “maraṇassati, bhikkhave, bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṃsā amatogadhā amatapariyosānā.
an8.73:1.6.eng: “Mendicants, when mindfulness of death is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. It has freedom from death as its objective and culmination.

an8.73:1.7.eng: But do you develop mindfulness of death?”

an8.73:2.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an8.73:2.1.eng: When he said this, one of the mendicants said to the Buddha,

an8.73:2.3.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhāvesi maraṇassatin”ti?
an8.73:2.3.eng: “But mendicant, how do you develop it?”

an8.73:2.5.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ rattindivaṃ jīveyyaṃ, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an8.73:2.5.eng: ‘Oh, if I’d only live for another day and night, I’d focus on the Buddha’s instructions and I could really achieve a lot.’

an8.73:2.6.pli: Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhāvemi maraṇassatin”ti.
an8.73:2.6.eng: That’s how I develop mindfulness of death.”

an8.73:3.1.eng: Another mendicant said to the Buddha,

an8.73:3.2.eng: “Sir, I too develop mindfulness of death.”

an8.73:3.3.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhāvesi maraṇassatin”ti?
an8.73:3.3.eng: “But mendicant, how do you develop it?”

an8.73:3.5.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ divasaṃ jīveyyaṃ, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an8.73:3.5.eng: ‘Oh, if I’d only live for another day, I’d focus on the Buddha’s instructions and I could really achieve a lot.’

an8.73:3.6.pli: Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhāvemi maraṇassatin”ti.
an8.73:3.6.eng: That’s how I develop mindfulness of death.”

an8.73:4.1.eng: Another mendicant said to the Buddha,

an8.73:4.2.eng: “Sir, I too develop mindfulness of death.”

an8.73:4.3.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhāvesi maraṇassatin”ti?
an8.73:4.3.eng: “But mendicant, how do you develop it?”

an8.73:4.5.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ upaḍḍhadivasaṃ jīveyyaṃ, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an8.73:4.5.eng: ‘Oh, if I’d only live for half a day, I’d focus on the Buddha’s instructions and I could really achieve a lot.’

an8.73:4.6.pli: Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhāvemi maraṇassatin”ti.
an8.73:4.6.eng: That’s how I develop mindfulness of death.”

an8.73:5.1.eng: Another mendicant said to the Buddha,

an8.73:5.2.eng: “Sir, I too develop mindfulness of death.”

an8.73:5.3.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhāvesi maraṇassatin”ti?
an8.73:5.3.eng: “But mendicant, how do you develop it?”

an8.73:5.5.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ tadantaraṃ jīveyyaṃ yadantaraṃ ekapiṇḍapātaṃ bhuñjāmi, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an8.73:5.5.eng: ‘Oh, if I’d only live as long as it takes to eat a single almsmeal, I’d focus on the Buddha’s instructions and I could really achieve a lot.’

an8.73:5.6.pli: Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhāvemi maraṇassatin”ti.
an8.73:5.6.eng: That’s how I develop mindfulness of death.”

an8.73:6.1.eng: Another mendicant said to the Buddha,

an8.73:6.2.eng: “Sir, I too develop mindfulness of death.”

an8.73:6.3.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhāvesi maraṇassatin”ti?
an8.73:6.3.eng: “But mendicant, how do you develop it?”

an8.73:6.5.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ tadantaraṃ jīveyyaṃ yadantaraṃ upaḍḍhapiṇḍapātaṃ bhuñjāmi, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an8.73:6.5.eng: ‘Oh, if I’d only live as long as it takes to eat half an almsmeal, I’d focus on the Buddha’s instructions and I could really achieve a lot.’

an8.73:6.6.pli: Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhāvemi maraṇassatin”ti.
an8.73:6.6.eng: That’s how I develop mindfulness of death.”

an8.73:7.1.eng: Another mendicant said to the Buddha,

an8.73:7.2.eng: “Sir, I too develop mindfulness of death.”

an8.73:7.3.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhāvesi maraṇassatin”ti?
an8.73:7.3.eng: “But mendicant, how do you develop it?”

an8.73:7.5.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ tadantaraṃ jīveyyaṃ yadantaraṃ cattāro pañca ālope saṅkhāditvā ajjhoharāmi, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an8.73:7.5.eng: ‘Oh, if I’d only live as long as it takes to chew and swallow four or five mouthfuls, I’d focus on the Buddha’s instructions and I could really achieve a lot.’

an8.73:7.6.pli: Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhāvemi maraṇassatin”ti.
an8.73:7.6.eng: That’s how I develop mindfulness of death.”

an8.73:8.1.eng: Another mendicant said to the Buddha,

an8.73:8.2.eng: “Sir, I too develop mindfulness of death.”

an8.73:8.3.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhāvesi maraṇassatin”ti?
an8.73:8.3.eng: “But mendicant, how do you develop it?”

an8.73:8.5.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ tadantaraṃ jīveyyaṃ yadantaraṃ ekaṃ ālopaṃ saṅkhāditvā ajjhoharāmi, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an8.73:8.5.eng: ‘Oh, if I’d only live as long as it takes to chew and swallow a single mouthful, I’d focus on the Buddha’s instructions and I could really achieve a lot.’

an8.73:8.6.pli: Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhāvemi maraṇassatin”ti.
an8.73:8.6.eng: That’s how I develop mindfulness of death.”

an8.73:9.1.eng: Another mendicant said to the Buddha,

an8.73:9.2.eng: “Sir, I too develop mindfulness of death.”

an8.73:9.3.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhāvesi maraṇassatin”ti?
an8.73:9.3.eng: “But mendicant, how do you develop it?”

an8.73:9.5.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ tadantaraṃ jīveyyaṃ yadantaraṃ assasitvā vā passasāmi, passasitvā vā assasāmi, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an8.73:9.5.eng: ‘Oh, if I’d only live as long as it takes to breathe out after breathing in, or to breathe in after breathing out, I’d focus on the Buddha’s instructions and I could really achieve a lot.’

an8.73:9.6.pli: Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhāvemi maraṇassatin”ti.
an8.73:9.6.eng: That’s how I develop mindfulness of death.”

an8.73:10.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhagavā te bhikkhū etadavoca:
an8.73:10.1.eng: When this was said, the Buddha said to those mendicants:

an8.73:10.2.eng: “The mendicants who develop mindfulness of death by wishing

an8.73:10.3.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ rattindivaṃ jīveyyaṃ, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an8.73:10.3.eng: to live for a day and night …

an8.73:10.4.pli: Yo cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ maraṇassatiṃ bhāveti:

an8.73:10.5.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ divasaṃ jīveyyaṃ, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti;
an8.73:10.5.eng: or to live for a day …

an8.73:10.6.pli: yo cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ maraṇassatiṃ bhāveti:

an8.73:10.7.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ upaḍḍhadivasaṃ jīveyyaṃ, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an8.73:10.7.eng: or to live for half a day …

an8.73:10.8.pli: Yo cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ maraṇassatiṃ bhāveti:

an8.73:10.9.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ tadantaraṃ jīveyyaṃ yadantaraṃ ekapiṇḍapātaṃ bhuñjāmi, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti;
an8.73:10.9.eng: or to live as long as it takes to eat a meal of almsfood …

an8.73:10.10.pli: yo cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ maraṇassatiṃ bhāveti:

an8.73:10.11.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ tadantaraṃ jīveyyaṃ yadantaraṃ upaḍḍhapiṇḍapātaṃ bhuñjāmi, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an8.73:10.11.eng: or to live as long as it takes to eat half a meal of almsfood …

an8.73:10.12.pli: Yo cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ maraṇassatiṃ bhāveti:

an8.73:10.13.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ tadantaraṃ jīveyyaṃ yadantaraṃ cattāro pañca ālope saṅkhāditvā ajjhoharāmi, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti—
an8.73:10.13.eng: or to live as long as it takes to chew and swallow four or five mouthfuls …

an8.73:10.14.pli: ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, ‘bhikkhū pamattā viharanti, dandhaṃ maraṇassatiṃ bhāventi āsavānaṃ khayāya’.
an8.73:10.14.eng: These are called mendicants who live negligently. They slackly develop mindfulness of death for the ending of defilements.

an8.73:11.1.pli: Yo ca khvāyaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ maraṇassatiṃ bhāveti:
an8.73:11.1.eng: But the mendicants who develop mindfulness of death by wishing

an8.73:11.2.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ tadantaraṃ jīveyyaṃ yadantaraṃ ekaṃ ālopaṃ saṅkhāditvā ajjhoharāmi, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an8.73:11.2.eng: to live as long as it takes to chew and swallow a single mouthful …

an8.73:11.3.pli: Yo cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ maraṇassatiṃ bhāveti:

an8.73:11.4.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ tadantaraṃ jīveyyaṃ yadantaraṃ assasitvā vā passasāmi, passasitvā vā assasāmi, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti—
an8.73:11.4.eng: or to live as long as it takes to breathe out after breathing in, or to breathe in after breathing out …

an8.73:11.5.pli: ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, ‘bhikkhū appamattā viharanti, tikkhaṃ maraṇassatiṃ bhāventi āsavānaṃ khayāya’.
an8.73:11.5.eng: These are called mendicants who live diligently. They keenly develop mindfulness of death for the ending of defilements.

an8.73:12.1.eng: So you should train like this:

an8.73:12.2.pli: ‘appamattā viharissāma, tikkhaṃ maraṇassatiṃ bhāvayissāma āsavānaṃ khayāyā’ti.
an8.73:12.2.eng: ‘We will live diligently. We will keenly develop mindfulness of death for the ending of defilements.’

an8.74:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā nātike viharati giñjakāvasathe.
an8.74:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying at Ñātika in the brick house.

an8.74:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

an8.74:1.3.pli: maraṇassati, bhikkhave, bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṃsā amatogadhā amatapariyosānā.
an8.74:1.3.eng: “Mendicants, when mindfulness of death is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. It has freedom from death as its objective and culmination.

an8.74:2.1.pli: Kathaṃ bhāvitā ca, bhikkhave, maraṇassati kathaṃ bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṃsā amatogadhā amatapariyosānā?
an8.74:2.1.eng: And how is mindfulness of death developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial, with freedom from death as its objective and culmination?

an8.74:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu divase nikkhante rattiyā patihitāya iti paṭisañcikkhati:
an8.74:2.2.eng: As day passes by and night draws close, a mendicant reflects:

an8.74:2.4.pli: ahi vā maṃ ḍaṃseyya, vicchiko vā maṃ ḍaṃseyya, satapadī vā maṃ ḍaṃseyya;
an8.74:2.4.eng: A snake might bite me, or a scorpion or centipede might sting me.

an8.74:2.5.pli: tena me assa kālakiriyā. So mama assa antarāyo.
an8.74:2.5.eng: And if I died from that it would be an obstacle to my progress.

an8.74:2.6.pli: Upakkhalitvā vā papateyyaṃ, bhattaṃ vā me bhuttaṃ byāpajjeyya, pittaṃ vā me kuppeyya, semhaṃ vā me kuppeyya, satthakā vā me vātā kuppeyyuṃ, manussā vā maṃ upakkameyyuṃ, amanussā vā maṃ upakkameyyuṃ;
an8.74:2.6.eng: Or I might stumble off a cliff, or get food poisoning, or suffer a disturbance of bile, phlegm, or piercing winds. Or I might be attacked by humans or non-humans.

an8.74:2.7.pli: tena me assa kālakiriyā. So mama assa antarāyo’ti.
an8.74:2.7.eng: And if I died from that it would be an obstacle to my progress.’

an8.74:2.9.pli: ‘atthi nu kho me pāpakā akusalā dhammā appahīnā ye me assu rattiṃ kālaṃ karontassa antarāyāyā’ti.
an8.74:2.9.eng: ‘Are there any bad, unskillful qualities that I haven’t given up, which might be an obstacle to my progress if I die tonight?’

an8.74:3.1.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṃ jānāti:
an8.74:3.1.eng: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that

an8.74:3.2.pli: ‘atthi me pāpakā akusalā dhammā appahīnā ye me assu rattiṃ kālaṃ karontassa antarāyāyā’ti, tena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā tesaṃyeva pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya adhimatto chando ca vāyāmo ca ussāho ca ussoḷhī ca appaṭivānī ca sati ca sampajaññañca karaṇīyaṃ.
an8.74:3.2.eng: there are such bad, unskillful qualities. Then in order to give them up they should apply extraordinary enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.

an8.74:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ādittacelo vā ādittasīso vā tasseva celassa vā sīsassa vā nibbāpanāya adhimattaṃ chandañca vāyāmañca ussāhañca ussoḷhiñca appaṭivāniñca satiñca sampajaññañca kareyya;
an8.74:4.1.eng: Suppose your clothes or head were on fire. In order to extinguish it, you’d apply extraordinary enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.

an8.74:4.2.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tena bhikkhunā tesaṃyeva pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya adhimatto chando ca vāyāmo ca ussāho ca ussoḷhī ca appaṭivānī ca sati ca sampajaññañca karaṇīyaṃ.
an8.74:4.2.eng: In the same way, in order to give up those bad, unskillful qualities, that mendicant should apply extraordinary enthusiasm …

an8.74:5.1.pli: Sace pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṃ jānāti:
an8.74:5.1.eng: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that

an8.74:5.2.pli: ‘natthi me pāpakā akusalā dhammā appahīnā ye me assu rattiṃ kālaṃ karontassa antarāyāyā’ti, tena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā teneva pītipāmojjena vihātabbaṃ ahorattānusikkhinā kusalesu dhammesu.
an8.74:5.2.eng: there are no such bad, unskillful qualities. Then that mendicant should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.

an8.74:6.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu rattiyā nikkhantāya divase patihite iti paṭisañcikkhati:
an8.74:6.1.eng: Or else, as night passes by and day draws close, a mendicant reflects:

an8.74:6.3.pli: ahi vā maṃ ḍaṃseyya, vicchiko vā maṃ ḍaṃseyya, satapadī vā maṃ ḍaṃseyya;
an8.74:6.3.eng: A snake might bite me, or a scorpion or centipede might sting me.

an8.74:6.4.pli: tena me assa kālakiriyā. So mama assa antarāyo.
an8.74:6.4.eng: And if I died from that it would be an obstacle to my progress.

an8.74:6.5.pli: Upakkhalitvā vā papateyyaṃ, bhattaṃ vā me bhuttaṃ byāpajjeyya, pittaṃ vā me kuppeyya, semhaṃ vā me kuppeyya, satthakā vā me vātā kuppeyyuṃ, manussā vā maṃ upakkameyyuṃ, amanussā vā maṃ upakkameyyuṃ;
an8.74:6.5.eng: Or I might stumble off a cliff, or get food poisoning, or suffer a disturbance of bile, phlegm, or piercing winds. Or I might be attacked by humans or non-humans.

an8.74:6.6.pli: tena me assa kālakiriyā. So mama assa antarāyo’ti.
an8.74:6.6.eng: And if I died from that it would be an obstacle to my progress.’

an8.74:6.8.pli: ‘atthi nu kho me pāpakā akusalā dhammā appahīnā ye me assu divā kālaṃ karontassa antarāyāyā’ti.
an8.74:6.8.eng: ‘Are there any bad, unskillful qualities that I haven’t given up, which might be an obstacle to my progress if I die today?’

an8.74:7.1.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṃ jānāti:
an8.74:7.1.eng: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that

an8.74:7.2.pli: ‘atthi me pāpakā akusalā dhammā appahīnā ye me assu divā kālaṃ karontassa antarāyāyā’ti, tena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā tesaṃyeva pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya adhimatto chando ca vāyāmo ca ussāho ca ussoḷhī ca appaṭivānī ca sati ca sampajaññañca karaṇīyaṃ.
an8.74:7.2.eng: there are such bad, unskillful qualities. Then in order to give them up they should apply extraordinary enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.

an8.74:8.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ādittacelo vā ādittasīso vā tasseva celassa vā sīsassa vā nibbāpanāya adhimattaṃ chandañca vāyāmañca ussāhañca ussoḷhiñca appaṭivāniñca satiñca sampajaññañca kareyya;
an8.74:8.1.eng: Suppose your clothes or head were on fire. In order to extinguish it, you’d apply extraordinary enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.

an8.74:8.2.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tena bhikkhunā tesaṃyeva pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya adhimatto chando ca vāyāmo ca ussāho ca ussoḷhī ca appaṭivānī ca sati ca sampajaññañca karaṇīyaṃ.
an8.74:8.2.eng: In the same way, in order to give up those bad, unskillful qualities, that mendicant should apply extraordinary enthusiasm …

an8.74:9.1.pli: Sace pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṃ jānāti:
an8.74:9.1.eng: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that

an8.74:9.2.pli: ‘natthi me pāpakā akusalā dhammā appahīnā ye me assu divā kālaṃ karontassa antarāyāyā’ti, tena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā teneva pītipāmojjena vihātabbaṃ ahorattānusikkhinā kusalesu dhammesu.
an8.74:9.2.eng: there are no such bad, unskillful qualities. Then that mendicant should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.

an8.74:9.3.pli: Evaṃ bhāvitā kho, bhikkhave, maraṇassati evaṃ bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṃsā amatogadhā amatapariyosānā”ti.
an8.74:9.3.eng: Mindfulness of death, when developed and cultivated in this way, is very fruitful and beneficial. It has freedom from death as its objective and culmination.”

an8.75:1.3.pli: Uṭṭhānasampadā, ārakkhasampadā, kalyāṇamittatā, samajīvitā, saddhāsampadā, sīlasampadā, cāgasampadā, paññāsampadā—
an8.75:1.3.eng: Accomplishment in initiative, protection, good friendship, and balanced finances. And accomplishment in faith, ethics, generosity, and wisdom.

an8.75:3.4.eng: to well-being in lives to come.

an8.75:4.2.eng: of a faithful householder of discernment

an8.75:4.3.eng: are declared by the one who is truly named

an8.75:4.4.eng: to lead to happiness in both spheres,

an8.75:5.1.eng: welfare and benefit in this life,

an8.75:5.2.eng: and happiness in lives to come.

an8.75:5.3.eng: This is how, for a householder,

an8.76:1.3.pli: Uṭṭhānasampadā, ārakkhasampadā, kalyāṇamittatā, samajīvitā, saddhāsampadā, sīlasampadā, cāgasampadā, paññāsampadā.
an8.76:1.3.eng: Accomplishment in initiative, protection, good friendship, and balanced finances. And accomplishment in faith, ethics, generosity, and wisdom.

an8.76:1.4.eng: And what is accomplishment in initiative?

an8.76:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, kulaputto yena kammaṭṭhānena jīvitaṃ kappeti—
an8.76:1.5.eng: It’s when a gentleman earns a living by means such as

an8.76:1.6.pli: yadi kasiyā yadi vaṇijjāya yadi gorakkhena yadi issattena yadi rājaporisena yadi sippaññatarena—
an8.76:1.6.eng: farming, trade, raising cattle, archery, government service, or one of the professions.

an8.76:1.7.pli: tattha dakkho hoti analaso, tatrupāyāya vīmaṃsāya samannāgato, alaṃ kātuṃ alaṃ saṃvidhātunti.
an8.76:1.7.eng: He understands how to go about these things in order to complete and organize the work.

an8.76:1.8.eng: This is called accomplishment in initiative.

an8.76:2.1.eng: And what is accomplishment in protection?

an8.76:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, kulaputtassa bhogā honti uṭṭhānavīriyādhigatā bāhābalaparicitā sedāvakkhittā dhammikā dhammaladdhā te ārakkhena guttiyā sampādeti:
an8.76:2.2.eng: It’s when a gentleman owns legitimate wealth that he has earned by his own efforts and initiative, built up with his own hands, gathered by the sweat of the brow. He ensures it is guarded and protected, thinking:

an8.76:2.3.pli: ‘kinti me bhoge neva rājāno hareyyuṃ, na corā hareyyuṃ, na aggi ḍaheyya, na udakaṃ vaheyya, na appiyā dāyādā hareyyun’ti.
an8.76:2.3.eng: ‘How can I prevent my wealth from being taken by rulers or bandits, consumed by fire, swept away by flood, or taken by unloved heirs?’

an8.76:2.4.eng: This is called accomplishment in protection.

an8.76:3.1.eng: And what is accomplishment in good friendship?

an8.76:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, kulaputto yasmiṃ gāme vā nigame vā paṭivasati, tattha ye te honti gahapatī vā gahapatiputtā vā daharā vā vuddhasīlino vuddhā vā vuddhasīlino saddhāsampannā sīlasampannā cāgasampannā paññāsampannā, tehi saddhiṃ santiṭṭhati sallapati sākacchaṃ samāpajjati; yathārūpānaṃ saddhāsampannānaṃ saddhāsampadaṃ anusikkhati, yathārūpānaṃ sīlasampannānaṃ sīlasampadaṃ anusikkhati, yathārūpānaṃ cāgasampannānaṃ cāgasampadaṃ anusikkhati, yathārūpānaṃ paññāsampannānaṃ paññāsampadaṃ anusikkhati.
an8.76:3.2.eng: It’s when a gentleman resides in a town or village. And in that place there are householders or their children who may be young or old, but are mature in conduct, accomplished in faith, ethics, generosity, and wisdom. He associates with them, converses and engages in discussion. And he emulates the same kind of accomplishment in faith, ethics, generosity, and wisdom.

an8.76:3.3.eng: This is called accomplishment in good friendship.

an8.76:4.1.eng: And what is accomplishment in balanced finances?

an8.76:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, kulaputto āyañca bhogānaṃ viditvā vayañca bhogānaṃ viditvā samaṃ jīvikaṃ kappeti nāccogāḷhaṃ nātihīnaṃ: ‘evaṃ me āyo vayaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassati, na ca me vayo āyaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassatī’ti.
an8.76:4.2.eng: It’s when a gentleman, knowing his income and expenditure, balances his finances, being neither too extravagant nor too frugal. He thinks, ‘In this way my income will exceed my expenditure, not the reverse.’

an8.76:4.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, tulādhāro vā tulādhārantevāsī vā tulaṃ paggahetvā jānāti: ‘ettakena vā onataṃ, ettakena vā unnatan’ti;
an8.76:4.3.eng: It’s like an appraiser or their apprentice who, holding up the scales, knows that it’s low by this much or high by this much.

an8.76:4.4.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, kulaputto āyañca bhogānaṃ viditvā vayañca bhogānaṃ viditvā samaṃ jīvikaṃ kappeti nāccogāḷhaṃ nātihīnaṃ: ‘evaṃ me āyo vayaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassati, na ca me vayo āyaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassatī’ti.
an8.76:4.4.eng: In the same way, a gentleman, knowing his income and expenditure, balances his finances, being neither too extravagant nor too frugal. He thinks, ‘In this way my income will exceed my expenditure, not the reverse.’

an8.76:4.5.pli: Sacāyaṃ, bhikkhave, kulaputto appāyo samāno uḷāraṃ jīvikaṃ kappeti, tassa bhavanti vattāro ‘udumbarakhādī vāyaṃ kulaputto bhoge khādatī’ti.
an8.76:4.5.eng: If a gentleman has little income but an opulent life, people will say: ‘This gentleman eats their wealth like a fig-eater!’

an8.76:4.6.pli: Sace panāyaṃ, bhikkhave, kulaputto mahāyo samāno kasiraṃ jīvikaṃ kappeti, tassa bhavanti vattāro: ‘ajeṭṭhamaraṇaṃ vāyaṃ kulaputto marissatī’ti.
an8.76:4.6.eng: If a gentleman has a large income but a spartan life, people will say: ‘This gentleman is starving themselves to death!’

an8.76:4.7.pli: Yato ca khoyaṃ, bhikkhave, kulaputto āyañca bhogānaṃ viditvā vayañca bhogānaṃ viditvā samaṃ jīvikaṃ kappeti nāccogāḷhaṃ nātihīnaṃ: ‘evaṃ me āyo vayaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassati, na ca me vayo āyaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassatī’ti.
an8.76:4.7.eng: But a gentleman, knowing his income and expenditure, leads a balanced life, neither too extravagant nor too frugal, thinking, ‘In this way my income will exceed my expenditure, not the reverse.’

an8.76:4.8.eng: This is called accomplishment in balanced finances.

an8.76:5.1.eng: And what is accomplishment in faith?

an8.76:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, kulaputto saddho hoti, saddahati tathāgatassa bodhiṃ:
an8.76:5.2.eng: It’s when a gentleman has faith in the Realized One’s awakening:

an8.76:5.3.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
an8.76:5.3.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha … teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

an8.76:5.4.eng: This is called accomplishment in faith.

an8.76:6.1.eng: And what is accomplishment in ethics?

an8.76:6.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, kulaputto pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti …pe… surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭivirato hoti.
an8.76:6.2.eng: It’s when a gentleman doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, lie, or consume beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.

an8.76:6.3.eng: This is called accomplishment in ethics.

an8.76:7.1.eng: And what is accomplishment in generosity?

an8.76:7.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, kulaputto vigatamalamaccherena cetasā agāraṃ ajjhāvasati …pe… yācayogo dānasaṃvibhāgarato.
an8.76:7.2.eng: It’s when a gentleman lives at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.

an8.76:7.3.eng: This is called accomplishment in generosity.

an8.76:8.1.eng: And what is accomplishment in wisdom?

an8.76:8.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, kulaputto paññavā hoti …pe… sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā.
an8.76:8.2.eng: It’s when a gentleman is wise. He has the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

an8.76:8.3.eng: This is called accomplishment in wisdom.

an8.76:11.4.eng: to well-being in lives to come.

an8.76:12.2.eng: of a faithful householder of discernment

an8.76:12.3.eng: are declared by the one who is truly named

an8.76:12.4.eng: to lead to happiness in both spheres,

an8.76:13.1.eng: welfare and benefit in this life,

an8.76:13.3.eng: This is how, for a householder,
